extracted-table.table-caption: Summary of included articles analysing resting-state functional connectivity in patients with manifest cerebral small vessel disease (CSVD). We report imaging and clinical characteristics of patients included in each study, key steps in the acquisition and pre-processing of BOLD data, analysis of functional connectivity, and FC patterns found to be associated with CSVD. Descriptive statistics as extracted from articles are reported as mean ± standard deviation. Missing information is indicted by empty brackets ([]). Arrows indicate increased (↑) or reduced (↓) values, as well as positive (↗) and negative (↘) associations

caption.p: Summary of included articles analysing resting-state functional connectivity in patients with manifest cerebral small vessel disease (CSVD). We report imaging and clinical characteristics of patients included in each study, key steps in the acquisition and pre-processing of BOLD data, analysis of functional connectivity, and FC patterns found to be associated with CSVD. Descriptive statistics as extracted from articles are reported as mean ± standard deviation. Missing information is indicted by empty brackets ([]). Arrows indicate increased (↑) or reduced (↓) values, as well as positive (↗) and negative (↘) associations

td.p: ↓ FC in DMN in the left middle temporal gyrus, left ant. cingulate/left middle frontal gyrus, right caudate, right middle frontal gyrus, and left medial frontal gyrus/paracentral lobule

ICA to define DMN, SMN, medial-visual RSN
Siemens Skyra/Prisma, 3 T, 64-/32-channel head coils, multi-band × 8
- Volume censoring (FD > 0.5 mm, total time < 5 min)
Power atlas to define DMN, FPCN, hand-SMN, VN
No association between WMH and FC
Poor reproducibility of network measures in CSVD
CONN atlas with 138 ROIs to define DMN, SMN, VN, DAN, FPCN language, and cerebellar networks
↓ FC between left SMA and temporal lobe (GC+ < GD−) ↗ gait speed

Table 1
Summary of included articles analysing resting-state functional connectivity in patients with manifest cerebral small vessel disease (CSVD). We report imaging and clinical characteristics of patients included in each study, key steps in the acquisition and pre-processing of BOLD data, analysis of functional connectivity, and FC patterns found to be associated with CSVD. Descriptive statistics as extracted from articles are reported as mean ± standard deviation. Missing information is indicted by empty brackets ([]). Arrows indicate increased (↑) or reduced (↓) values, as well as positive (↗) and negative (↘) associations
ReferenceParticipantsCharacteristics of patients with CSVDMRI acquisition paramsBOLD pre-processingFC analysisFC patterns associated with CSVDRisk of bias (AXIS)

extracted-table.table-caption: Summary of included articles analysing resting-state functional connectivity in healthy participants or patients without vascular cognitive impairment. We report imaging and clinical characteristics of patients included in each study, key steps in the acquisition and pre-processing of BOLD data, analysis of functional connectivity, and FC patterns found to be associated with CSVD. Descriptive statistics as extracted from articles are reported as range (min–max) and/or mean ± standard deviation. Missing information is indicted by empty brackets ([]). Reported are clinical characteristics of patients included in each study, details about the quantification of white matter hyperintensities, key steps in the analysis of functional connectivity, and FC patterns found to be associated with CSVD. Arrows indicate increased (↑) or reduced (↓) values, as well as positive (↗) and negative (↘) associations

caption.p: Summary of included articles analysing resting-state functional connectivity in healthy participants or patients without vascular cognitive impairment. We report imaging and clinical characteristics of patients included in each study, key steps in the acquisition and pre-processing of BOLD data, analysis of functional connectivity, and FC patterns found to be associated with CSVD. Descriptive statistics as extracted from articles are reported as range (min–max) and/or mean ± standard deviation. Missing information is indicted by empty brackets ([]). Reported are clinical characteristics of patients included in each study, details about the quantification of white matter hyperintensities, key steps in the analysis of functional connectivity, and FC patterns found to be associated with CSVD. Arrows indicate increased (↑) or reduced (↓) values, as well as positive (↗) and negative (↘) associations

tr.td: FC in DMN ↘ WMH in medial PFC
↓ Association between DMN-FC and treatment response after controlling for WMH load

td.p: Medial PFC and PCC from ext. atlas

tr.td: Both increased WMH load and reduced DMN-FC in AD and MCI compared to HC
SCA from the hippocampus and PCC
No association between WMH load and FC
No association between WMH and FC

td.p: Preselected cognitive control networks (FPCN, SN) + DMN

tr.td: Weaker negative association between executive function/memory and WMH load in patients with high global FC
↑ FC between right middle cingulate cortex and right parahippocampal gyrus
FC ↗ WMH left hippocampus and right inf. orbital and inf. temporal gyrus

td.p: No association between WMH load and FC
Episodic memory ↗ medial PFC–left inferior parietal cortex FC in patients with low grey matter volume
PCC and medial PFC from external DMN template

tr.td: ↓ Association between PCC-medial PFC FC and mean diffusivity in cingulum bundle

td.p: Template-based rotation to define DMN and FPCN

tr.td: No association between WMH load and FC
ICA to define DMN, SN, FPN, VN

td.p: FC in DMN ↗ WMH in the mediotemporal complex
FC in SN ↗ WMH in the right S1 and sup./inf. parietal cortex
- Max FD > 0.5 mm, abs. motion > 3 mm

tr.td: FC ↘ WMH both tract-specific and global

td.p: ICA to define DMN, SMN, FPCN

tr.td: No association between WMH load and FC
Coarse-to-fine in-house developed mathematical morphology method [88]

td.p: FC in the left cuneus and right sup. occipital cortex ↗ WMH in the right ant. corona radiata
FC in the left superior occipital cortex ↗ WMH in the right superior corona radiata

tr.td: Pattern of advanced brain ageing characterised by both increased WMH burden and reduced FC compared to resilient agers
Automated regression algorithm [90] using a Hidden Markov Random Field with Expectation Maximization [91]
No association between WMH load and DMN FC trajectories

td.p: Mean FD as covariate in analysis

tr.td: No association between WMH load and FC
FC ↗ WMH in right orbitofrontal cortex

td.p: Template-based rotation to define DMN, SMN, DMN, and FPCN
Association between WMH load and FC not investigated
FC in DMN ↘ risk of progression to MCI

Table 2
Summary of included articles analysing resting-state functional connectivity in healthy participants or patients without vascular cognitive impairment. We report imaging and clinical characteristics of patients included in each study, key steps in the acquisition and pre-processing of BOLD data, analysis of functional connectivity, and FC patterns found to be associated with CSVD. Descriptive statistics as extracted from articles are reported as range (min–max) and/or mean ± standard deviation. Missing information is indicted by empty brackets ([]). Reported are clinical characteristics of patients included in each study, details about the quantification of white matter hyperintensities, key steps in the analysis of functional connectivity, and FC patterns found to be associated with CSVD. Arrows indicate increased (↑) or reduced (↓) values, as well as positive (↗) and negative (↘) associations

extracted-table.table-caption: Summary of reported associations between altered FC patterns in CSVD and cognitive ability. Arrows indicate positive (↗) and negative (↘) associations

caption.p: Summary of reported associations between altered FC patterns in CSVD and cognitive ability. Arrows indicate positive (↗) and negative (↘) associations

tr.td: MMSE ↗ FC between the left thalamus–left orbitofrontal lobe

td.p: MMSE ↗ ReHo in the right angular gyrus and precuneus
MoCA ↗ ReHo in the bilateral angular gyrus, the right precuneus, medial/dorsolateral PFC, and supplementary motor area
MMSE ↗ FC right precentral–right calcarine fissure, left posterior inferior parietal lobe–left Heschl, right posterior inferior parietal lobe–right dorsolateral PFC
MMSE ↘ FC right posterior inferior parietal lobe–left Heschl, left intraparietal sulcus–right superior temporal gyrus
MoCA ↗ FC right posterior inferior parietal lobe–right anterior PFC, right posterior inferior parietal lobe–right dorsolateral PFC
MoCA ↘ FC right posterior inferior parietal lobe–left Heschl, left intraparietal sulcus–right superior temporal gyrus

tr.td: MMSE ↘ parieto-occipital FC in patients with confluent WMH

td.p: Phonemic fluency ↗ FC in bilateral sup. parietal lobe, SMA, premotor cortex, MCC, and posterior superior frontal sulcus
RTStroop, neutral ↘ FC in the bilateral premotor cortex, superior frontal sulcus, left inferior frontal sulcus, left SMA, left middle temporal sulcus, and right MCC
RTStroop, neutral ↗ FC in the inferior parietal lobe and cerebellar lobules Crus II, VIIb, and VIII
RTTMT-A ↘ FC in the bilateral premotor cortex, left posterior middle frontal gyrus, left inferior frontal sulcus, right superior parietal lobe, and left SMA
RTStroop, incongruent ↘ FC in the left premotor cortex/posterior middle frontal gyrus
RTStroop, incongruent ↗ FC in the cerebellar regions VI, Crus I, and Crus II
Letter/category fluency, letter-number sequencing of the WAIS-III, Digit Span Backward of the WAIS revised (WAIS-R), Self-Ordered Pointing task, mod. Flanker task, and TMT A/B

tr.td: Executive function ↗ FC-SC decoupling in DMN
Executive function ↗ FC in the right cingulate motor area
Time interference index ↗ FC in anterior DMN and SN

td.p: Association (executive function ↘ WMH) attenuated in patients with high global FC in FPCN
Associations (executive function ↘ WMH) and (memory ↘ WMH attenuated) in patients with high local FC in SN
RTTMT-A ↘ FC in FPCN in the right inferior parietal lobule
RTTMT-A ↘ FC between the dorsolateral PFC and DMN between bilateral PCC and right precuneus
Stroop C score ↗ path length, ↘ global efficiency
Delayed recall ↘ participation coefficient left superior parietal lobule
FC ↘ long recall between right olfactory–right rectus; ↘ short recall between right olfactory–left pallidum
FC ↗ RTTMT-A between right olfactory–left pallidum
